item.title: Maria Terrell
item.description:
December 23, 1959 - February 27, 2022
Maria Antoinette Vercher Terrell was born to Jerline Sears Adwater and James Murner Vercher
(both proceeded her in death) in Compton, California on December 23, 1959.
Maria A. Terrell was the 3rd oldest of 10 children. She was an excellent daughter, sister, wife, mother.
Nana, Niece, cousin, and friend.

She began her education in the Compton Unified School District, she attended at El Segundo
Elementary and Willowbrook Middle school after which she went on to forward her education and
graduated from college where she studied Word Processing. Maria worked for the Los Angeles
County Department of Public and Social Services for several years.

Being raised in a large family she was never without friends and made friends easily wherever she
went. Maria enjoyed being around family, laughing, Playing cards, dancing, and listening to music;
Gospel, R&B and Reggae were her favorites. She especially loved playing Baseball, playing games
and watching movies.

Maria accepted Christ as her Lord and Savior at a very young age. She had 4 beautiful children. She
met the love her life and on September 27, 1986, she and Randall D. Terrell were married in the city
of Compton, California.

Maria was a beautiful woman inside and out. Everyone that knew Maria knew her to be very strong
and always carried herself as a lady. She had such a beautiful smile and a beautiful heart.
She loved her husband and has always been loyal and loving. They were best friends and shared
many years of love and fun times together. He describes her as the best part of him, his heart and his
soul mate. She was his everything and she loved him unconditionally.

As a mother, Maria was always fun to be around and kept everyone laughing. She loved her children
unconditionally with everything in her being. She taught her children to love others and self-love,
independence, to always strive for the best, never give up and never depend on others. She
showed them guidance, support, taught them wisdom, how to work hard for what you want, never
judge others despite their faults and most importantly always, always stay prayed up. Maria showed
them strength even at her weakest. She never wanted her children to see the pain she bore daily.
She always greeted them with a smile and a big hug.

Maria leaves to cherish her memory, her husband, Randall D. Terrell, 4 children, Taria L. Scrivens,
Edwin and Demetria Scrivens, Ronnie G. Scrivens, and Mia Terrell, twelve siblings, Patti Sears
Woods, Lawrence and Regina Sears, Sharon Vercher, Tina Vercher, Placeed and Taquesha Vercher,
Antoin Vercher, Delava Lang(deceased), Terrell and Darrell Washington, Montrail and Kela Verchel,
10 brothers and sister in laws, 15 grandchildren, 10 great grandchildren who loved their Nana vely
much, a host of nephews and nieces family and friends who also loved her very much. Maria Will be
dearly missed forever.
]]>

item.title: Dorothy Hollins
item.description:
March 23, 1930 - March 14, 2022
Viewing
9:30am-10:00am

Mass
10:00am-11:00am

St. John Neumann Catholic Church
2575 W. El Campo Grande Avenue
North Las Vegas, NV 89031
On March 23, 1930, Dorothy Mae Hollins, the eldest of 13 children was born to the late Eugene and Susanna Dorsey in
Maringouin, LA. Early on she was baptized into the Catholic faith and continued to practice Catholicism as a member of
St. Albert the Great Catholic Church, in Compton, CA for over 25 years and later at St. John Neumann Catholic Church in
Las Vegas, NV until her transition.
Dorothy began her education at West Oak Lane where she attended and completed 7th grade. At the age of 21 she moved to
California. Being raised in a large family, Dorothy organically developed her housekeeping and caregiver skillets. She later
used these abilities to attain several domestic positions. One of her most significant roles, was the "day's work" she performed
for Dr. and Mrs. Jackson and their children. Dorothy cherished the time she spent with the Jackson family and would often
share stories from her experiences there, such as eating Mrs. Jackson's bread, the preschool age Jackson girls sneaking out to
"Kiddie Land" or how she feared the local reptiles near the Jackson home.
When her first husband Sterling Robertson transitioned in 1976, she sought full-time work to support her family. Dorothy
then began her career with Kaiser Permanente and retired with 18 years of service in 1994. She trained and mentored others
on the proper way to prepare hospital rooms for surgery. Dorothy fully committed to excelling in any job she was given, and
her work ethic was unparalleled.
Dorothy married her second husband in 1986 William (Bill) Hollins and together they relocated to North Las Vegas, NV. Here
is where she began to expand her love for dogs. So much so, she would often make trips to Los Angeles with her beloved "Petey".
In her spare time, you could find Dorothy gardening and manicuring her lawn. She grew a variety of vegetables and fruits,
such as okra, tomatoes, collard greens, and apricots. At times there was more produce than she could consume, so you would
find Dorothy knocking on her neighbor's doors sharing her yield.
Dorothy assumed the mother and grandmother role to many outside of her family. She would congratulate, praise or reprimand
anyone deserving the response. Although she wasn't large in stature, she would assertively tell complete strangers, "Now you
know you need a jacket on" with that uniquely high-pitched voice of hers. Being the eldest of 13 children, family was always
first priority and she made herself available to them. Rather it be just to say hello and I love you or to make sure you took
your medicine and followed doctor's orders. Dorothy was an innated caregiver.
To cherish her memory, Dorothy leaves behind her daughter, Joycelyn Dorsey; grandchildren, Camile Bowie and Christopher
Cavalier; sisters, Mattie Young, Susie Dorsey, Janice Womber, Elizabeth Ann Scott, Eugenia Crook and Glenda Donaldson;
brothers, Harold Dorsey and Donald Dorsey; God-appointed daughters, Robin Coleman, Jennifer Jackson, Jody Jackson and
Diana Jackson, eight great-grandchildren; an aunt, Dorothy Dorsey and a host of nieces, nephews and cousins.
She was preceded in death by her husband; William Hollins; parents, Susanna and Eugene Dorsey; daughter, Gail Robertson;
sisters, Geneva Dixon, Shirley Mae Foy, and Mildred Anderson; and brother, Eddie Dorsey.

De'Ari Brielle Geraldine Shelby was introduced to this world by her
Heavenly Father to her parents Ivony Montgomery and DeAndre Shelby on
Wednesday, October 27, 2021. After a brief work assignment sanctioned by
God, she was called to her heavenly home, on Thursday, March 4, 2022, at
Sunrise Children's Hospital.

'How quietly you tiptoed into our world, almost silently, only for a moment
you stayedâ¦but what an imprint your footprints have left upon our hearts.'

De'Ari was preceded in
death by grandmother, Jerry Montgomery;
grandfather, Charles Swindell; and aunt, Geraldine Montgomery. She was a
very happy baby and always had a big smile on her face until she wanted to
*Put On' to get some attention and be held. De' Ari was a daddy's girl for sure.
She would cry BIG fake tears to get her dad's attention and once she had it,
she would look right at you and start laughing. De' Ari loved her bouncer and
to sit up so she could be nosey. She loved to watch the TV shows
'Wishenpoof" and "Word Party"

De'Ari loved her siblings and had a different bond with each of them. She
was also called by a few different names: "DeAir", "Phatty", "Butterball"
"Pretty Girl', and "Princess"

De Ari leaves to mourn her mommy, Ivony Montgomery; daddy, DeAndre
Shelby; four siblings, Aniya Taylor, Na'laiya Taylor, Zhaire Taylor, and
/Andrea Shelby; grandmother, Katrina Shelby; grandfather, Mario Shelby, Sr.
three aunts, Evory Montgomery, Linda Montgomery, Emily Hernandez:
seven uncles, Mario Shelby, Jr., Dominic Shelby, Demetrius Shelby, Marcus
Hernandez, Zakquery Hernandez, Tory Hernandez, and David Hernandez:
honorary aunt, Towvette Tillery; honorary grandmother, Veronica Williams.
great-great uncle, Jerry Swindell; and, a host of cousins across the country.

item.title: James Tarver
item.description:
October 21, 1924 - March 7, 2022
ï»¿Viewing & Service
ï»¿11:00am - 2:00pm
ï»¿Monday, March 14, 2022

Serenity Funeral Home
ï»¿1140 Almond Tree Lane
ï»¿Las Vegas, NV, 89104
James Louis Tarver, born October 21, 1924, to Bertha and Louis Tarver, in Madison, Illinois. James was an only child, which explains a lot. The family would later move to Birmingham, Alabama where he grew up and called home.Â 

Early years

James was a curious little boy and loved school an his classmates. During elementary school he was president of the Safety Council, Jr. Red cross, and Class President. Academics were easy for James, and he excelled in history and math. His love for music led to learning to play the drums and he medaled in track and field running the 80 and 100 yard dash and 220 relay.Â 

During the high school years, James was the Vice President of the Student Body Council and President of the Usher Club. In his senior year, dad was drafted for World War II and proudly served his country. After the war he found work with US Plywood as a truck driver and lived life to the fullest. It wouldn't be until 2007 that dad would receive a high school diploma. This honor meant a lot to dad as he never imagined he would get his diploma.Â 

California

James was looking for a change and decided to move to California and lived with his cousin. Taking a job in Loma Linda and meeting the love of his life Esther, was the best thing to ever happen to him. They would go on to have three children together, however, Mary his step-daughter made the family complete. With a new family and home within about 5 years, he was very happy.Â 

A new job was on the horizon and now James was working for the city of San Bernardino, as a Community Relations Specialist, in the Redevelopment Agency. This jpb allowed him to flourish with his social skills and his canny ability to easily strike up a conversation. He worked with many different people to help establish a recreation center for the Delman Heights Community.Â 

After a summer vacation to Omaha, Nebraska to visit a cousin, the decision was made to move there. Working for Western Electric only lasted 5 years and it was back to sunny California. James went to work for Santa Fe Railroad upon return to San Bernardino. This was home for the next 40 years. Coaching little league, bowling, photography, and vegetable gardening were some of dad's favorite things to do.

As James and Esther were aging, they decided to move to Las Vegas to be near their grandkids. Over the last 8 year Vegas was home for James and he loved seeing the grandkids and visiting his favorite casino, which was the one he would "win" at during that visit.Â 

James' outlook on life was to be grateful for your opportunities and go after "it". Don't wait for a handout and be your own person. This attitude served him well.Â 

In addition to raising four children, James also raised two grandsons Daniel and James. James is survived by his wife Esther Tarver, Daughters Beverly Winn and Mary Schwartz, sons Louis Tarver II and Charles Tarver III, grandchildren Daniel Tarver, Louis Tarver Jr, Ashley Kerrwinn, Joshua Bowden, Rosemary Morfin, James Tarver II, Charles Tarver,Â  great grand children Destiny, Desiree, Keira, Kyle, and Kaden Tarver, Adelina, Arianna, Jackson Morfin, Daniel Tarver Jr, and Michael and Raphael Bowen.Â 

James Louis Tarver was preceded in death by three siblings, his mother and father Bertha Mae and Louis Delaware Tarver.Â Â

Robert Arthur Anderson Jr.
BORN SEPTEMBER 19, 1940 TO ROBERT ANDERSON SR. AND VELMA RILEY
BOONE IN LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA. HE ACCEPTED CHRIST AT AN EARLY
AGE. HE GRADUATED FROM CENTENNIAL SENIOR HIGH SCHOOL JANUARY 26, 1968
IN COMPTON, CA. HE LATER JOINED THE US ARMY AND SPENT MOST OF HIS SERVICE IN VIETNAM.

IN 1968 HE BEGAN WORKING AT MAX FACTOR COSMETICS IN GARDENA
CALIFORNIA WHERE HE HAD A SPECIAL RELATIONSHIP WITH HIS CO-
WORKERS. HE LATER RETIRED FROM US FOODS IN LAS VEGAS NEVADA.

BOB, BOBBY, OR POPS ARE ALL THE NAMES HE WAS AFFECTIONALLY KNOWN
TO HIS FAMILY AND CLOSE FRIENDS. POPS WAS A JOY TO ALL WHO CAME
IN CONTACT WITH HIM. HIS GREATEST PLEASURE WAS TO BRING JOY AND
LAUGHTER TO WHOMEVER HE MET. HIS TIME, LOVE AND EFFORT WERE
DEVOTED TO HELPING OTHERS, ESPECIALLY HIS IMMEDIATE FAMILY.

POPS HOBBIES INCLUDED HIS LOVE OF MUSIC (OLDIES), DANCING, PLAYING
LOTTO, DOMINOES, BOWLING, HIS 49ERS AND COOKING.
HE CAME TO REST FEBRUARY 12, 2022. IN LOVING MEMORY HE LEAVES 4
SIBLINGS GLORIA SCOTT, SHIRLEY BOONE, ALICE SHACKELFORD, AND
ANTHONY BOONE, 4 CHILDREN, MAURICE ROBERTS, SHANEEKA ANDERSON,
SHANTE' ANDERSON AND TROY ANDERSON, 5 GRANDCHILDREN, AND A HOST
OF RELATIVES, IN-LAWS & FRIENDS.

PROCEEDED IN DEATH BY HIS MOTHER VELMA BOONE, HIS BROTHER
NATHANIEL BOONE, UNCLE CURTIS RELEIGHAND AND NEPHEW KEMMEL SHACKELFORD.

HE WILL BE TRULY MISSED!

Thelmar Jean Brown was born on July 23, 1951, she was
the eleventh of thirteen children born to the late Fred and
Mary Boley in Winnsboro, LA. Thelmar was baptized at
an early age at Sweet Home Baptist Church in Winnsboro, LA.

She graduated from Franklin Parish
High School in 1969. Thelmar later moved to Monroe in
1069 where she attended Delta Community College
where she studied business. In 1976, Thelmar moved to
Las Vegas, Nevada where she joined the City of
Las Vegas helping the youth in the community. She also
had an additional role of helping adults with disabilities,
where she was greatly loved and appreciated.

Thelmar also joined New Light Missionary Baptist Church.
Thelmar provided support and love to all her family and
was known as the caretaker of the family. In addition, she
was known as "the handy man / woman" of the family.

Thelmar was a loving and giving mother, grandmother, sister,
aunt, and friend. Thelmar enjoyed traveling and spending time with family.
Thelmar touched many lives with her warm and giving spirit,
her legacy will live on in all the lives she touched.
Her work here on earth was finished on Tuesday, February 15th, 2022,
now she is resting in the arms of the Lord.

She is preceded in death by her parents, sisters
Enda Williams, Eunice Boley, Martha Boley, Ruby Essissima,
Essie Boley, Cleather Boley-Johnson, Ora Gordon, and brother Fred Boley Jr.
Thelmar leaves to celebrate her life and continue her
legacy three daughters and one son: Tonya Coulberson
(Delaney) of Monroe LA, Monica Brown of Las Vegas
NV, Rentia Brown of Monroe LA, and Henry Brown
(Myke) of Las Vegas NV, ten grandchildren and four
great-grandchildren. Thelmar is survived by three siblings
Pearlie Stagg and Carl Boley of Winnsboro, LA and
Margrett Boley of Atlanta, Georgia.
She also leaves a host of nieces, nephews, cousins, and friends.

item.title: Curtis McHenry
item.description:
December 25, 1957 - February 18, 2022
On December 25, 1957, Curtis McHenry was born to Velma Lewis and Johnny Lee McHenry in Chicago, Illinois. He had 5 sisters Gail, Angie, Denise, Shay, Vivian, and 1 brother Ronnie. They were all in the church choir growing up. Curtis was the protector of the family and loved them dearly. Chicago wasn't a safe place to grow up due to riots and killings, Growing up Curtis was independent and did his own thing, he was a hustler and he always made sure he looked nice. He attended Tilden High School in Chicago. Chicago was bad in the 70's so he went up to Kansas City every summer. Curtis was a Smith Operator and he was one of the best Chicago bop dancers and 2 steppers out. He would take his little sister Gail to the club and dance with her because no one in Kansas City would do it.

Curtis was fly and smooth and everyone wanted to hang with him. He was really close to Dwayne and his cousin Michelle, they would go out in the town and do what fly young people do, clubbing, dancing, making money and having the time of their lives. They were a trio not to be played with, they were always clean and the center of attention. They would go to the pool hall fresh and sharp. They loved music so much and being out on the scene. Curt was the quiet one but strategic and they all held their own. They were something else in those days. Curt and Dwayne were out chasing money and the woman loved them. The trio did so much together and shared so many crazy good memories.

In the early 80's Curtis met the "finest girl he ever seen" as he would say, Debra Johnson. They were in love and inseparable. Debra got pregnant with their first kids Tyjunia in 1982, after the first 6 kids were conceived in Kansas, they moved to California. Curtis and Debra shared good and bad times but the love was always there, they had a love for music and Debra even said Curtis could hold a tune. Curtis and Debra had 10 kids together, Tyjunia, Curniece, Curtis, Cortez, Tiffany, Quincy, Christopher, Sheena, Carlos, and Chante. They both said they wanted a lot of kids. They shared more than 15 years together. Later down the line Curtis met Phyllis and conceived his 11th child Ashlee McHenry in the mid 90's. Curtis said Phyllis was so sweet and nice to him. They would cruise the coast and listen to music when they weren't out in the town. They would carpool to Vegas with their friends and eventually move down there. When Curtis moved to Las Vegas, he was an executive salesman at Hire Guns Advertisement. He was the top salesman at his company. In the 2000's his son Cortes and daughter Curniece joined him in Vegas. Eventually all his sons moved there as well, where they shared the rest of his life playing basketball, clubbing, and making memories.

Curtis continued to be the life of the party, He was still like a young man and never lost his swag. He still made sure he looked fresh and that he was driving something nice. He was going to enjoy his life to the end and do what he wanted to do with a smile on his face. He left an impact on many people and when you ask about Curtis, the people always say he was a smooth OG that taught them a few things and was such a cool guy, he was playa to the end.

item.description:
February 9, 1965 - January 22, 2022

Sunrise: February 9, 1965Â  Â  Â Sunset: January 22, 2022

Frank Maurice Morris was born to the proud parents of Frank and Betty Morris on February 9th, 1965 in Martinez, CA. He attended Peres Elementary School, Helmes Jr High, and graduated from Gompers High School in 1982. He later joined the labor union where he worked in construction holding several positions.

He was a youth baseball coach and also enjoyed playin basketball. Frank loved playing dominoes and hanging out with family and friends. Anybody who knew Frank knew that he loved watching pro wrestling. There wasn't a Monday that he didn't watch Smackdown. he didn't play about his wrestling. In 1985, Frank had his first child Franchelle Morris with his early wife Tracy Morris who proceeded him in death in 2019.

In 1988, he had a son, Freddie Morris, of Richmond, CA.

In the early 2000's, Frank remarried to a special lady, Linda Thompson.

In 2008, Frank accepted Christ and became a deacon at New Hope Baptist Church in Richmond, CA.

In 2021, he moved to Las Vegas, NV where he continued to work in the construction field. He spent his last years here with his family.

item.title: Diane Coleman
item.description:
July 30, 1951 - January 20, 2022

Sunrise: 7-30-1951Â  Â  Â Sunset: 1-20-2022

Diane was born in Toledo, Ohio on July 30, 1956 to the late John and Lovie Lucille Lee-Whitfield. Diane was raised in a loving home, she accepted the Lord Jesus Christ, at a early age. Diane's family settled in Detroit, Michigan when she was thirteen years old. She was the eldest, of the four children Erma Jean, John, and Steven. Detroit was truly her home, she graduated from Osborn High School where she advance in the honor role. Diane met and married the love of her life, Marion Lee Coleman, to this union they were blessed with three amazing daughters: Lovie, Felicia, and Paulette Coleman.

Diane had an "I can", attitude and a strong will. In 1956, Diane uprooted her girls and left Detroit to live in Los Angeles, California to follow her dreams. She earned a nursing degree and lived a life of service. She displayed a love of nursing, so much so, that her daughter Felicia was drawn into the same profession. During her career she had the pleasure of working with her daughter, the late Felicia Coleman-Saxton, for the State of California. Diane honorable retired from nursing after thirty years of dedicated service.

Diane believed you could do anything through the power of prayer. She loved to sew, read, dance, listen to music and spiritual programs. She was a strong woman and was committed to her family. She enjoyed gatherings with family and friends on many occasions, Spending time with grand and great grandchildren. She always had the answer to help you solve your problems, truly the backbone of our family. She modeled God, love, faith, and family. She will surely be missed.

item.title: Hugh Mosley
item.description:
December 5, 1956 - January 22, 2022
Hugh Terrell Mosley was born December 5, 1956 in Las Vegas NV, to Alma and Hugh Mosley. He was the second of three boys; some people know him as BB and some people know him as Terry. His brother Jerome called him Cheese and his father called him Mouse. His brother Leland recalls that when they were growing up, they played sports and was on several softball teams. Hugh was a prankster and along with his Cousin Chris they would play many pranks on his brother Jerome and Cousins Felicia and Michelle.

He graduated from Las Vegas high school class of 1974, and at school he was known for his many talents. Hugh played the clarinet in the Varsity Marching Band; he was also a track star. He placed first in many of his races and even won state. He was known on his track team as the galloping ghost because of speed.

From birth his mother took him to all the meetings at the Kingdom Hall and taught him about Jehovah, and as a child he never missed a convention and he travelled out of town to many of them. At a young age Hugh was teaching the Bible to the kids in his neighborhood and letting them know about Jehovah. He was very passionate about the resurrection, and telling people about how their dead loved ones would live again.

On July 8th 1972 Hugh was baptized as one of Jehovah Witnesses and attended meetings until his untimely death. He also knew that if he was to fall asleep in death, he will have a chance to live again in a peaceful world where he wouldn't have to worry about sickness, pain, and death anymore. On September 6th, 1975 Hugh married Gina Spencer. Hugh and Gina were married for over 46 years at the time of his death. Through their union they had four daughters and one son. Hugh was 17 years old when he started working in the culinary field, his first job was at the Mint hotel. He worked in the culinary field for over 36 years, until his health no longer allowed him to. Hugh had a chance to cook for everyone he even prepared a meal for the hall of fame baseball legend Ken Griffin Jr. and Frank Sinatra. If you knew Hugh you knew he was a huge sports fan. He'd talk sports every time he was able to do so. He was also a team parent no matter who the child was Hugh would help coach and guide them in their sport especially track and field. His favorite sports teams were the Raiders, LA Lakers and San Francisco Giants. Hugh had a saying "If you can't get down don't get down at all".

item.title: Annie Flowers
item.description:
August 24, 1945 - January 9, 2022
Annie Mae (Stark) Flowers was born August 24, 1945, to the union of Allen Stark Sr. and Fannie Mae Buie in Wiser, Louisiana where she attended the local high school, Wiser High. Annie met and married her husband of 21 years, Mr. Henry Lee Flowers Sr., in 1963. Early on, they decided to move their family to Las Vegas, NV for a new start. to this union God blesses them with 4 children; two sons, Henry Lee Flowers and Charles Edward Flowers; two daughters Connie Faye Ruiz and Angela Annette Lee, and a foster daughter, Balisha McCoy. While raising her childten and being a devoted wife, Annie Mae was also a caregiver for her father, who moved with her from Louisiana to Las Vegas. She also became a foster mother in 1984. Annie worked full time in the hospitality industry for 40 years as a Bell Person at the Tropicana Hotel and Casino and retired in 2008 after a long and successful career.

Annie Mae was a great cook and loved to share her gift of cooking with her family and friends. Many holidays were spent at her home, filled with love and the aroma of her special dishes. She also enjoyed road trips and loved sight seeing in each state.Â

item.title: Sarah Mayes
item.description:
February 5, 1956 - December 24, 2021
Sarah Lee Phelps was born in Tupelo, MS. on February 5, 1956 to Samuel Phelps and Robie Lee Vaughn Phelps. She shared a home along with 2 out of 4 siblings. Sarah was 7 when she and her siblings lost their mother. Sarah excelled in school despite not having a mother, graduating from Tupelo High School, and becoming a hard worker early on.

Sarah moved to Las Vegas in 1976 with Aunt Mamie Sue Vaughn Fields and joined the Culinary and Bartenders Union. Sarah grew up in church as a young child. Upon moving to Las Vegas, she was introduced to Buddhism through her cousin, Rosie Fields.

She worked at the Tropicana Hotel for a decade alongside her best friend, Sister Roberta Cowart. She also met other great friends, Barbara Jean, Chris, and Deloris.

Sarah moved to the Moulin Rouge in 1981 with her sister Bessie and family, where she met Carlos Mayes. The two dated and later married in 1986, making her, Sarah Lee Mayes. She later went on to work at the Hilton Hotel for another decade where Sarah retired to become a homemaker. She opened her home to any and everyone, all the while with a big smile and lots of love. She enjoyed cooking and eating. Sarah loved to go fishing with her husband and extended family. Willie and Margaret Smith. She loved to sing and collect albums and always jumped at the chance to get pictures of everyone. She was a vibrant soul, loyal friends, and a wonderful mother. Sarah confessed her life to rejoin Christ in 2005, being baptized once more under the leadership of Elder Seward Victorian. She moved to Lafayette, LA to be close to her sister for six years, until her health needed close supervision.

item.title: James Smith
item.description:
November 16, 1945 - January 20, 2022
Born November 16, 1945 in Menifee, Arkansas, From the late Merzetta and John Henry. He attended Conway Country High School of Menifee. He was also the 3rd oldest of 9 children, after graduating he went on to move to Kansas City, Missouri. He met and married Camelia Dorset they had two children, Kennon and Ladonna Smith.Â 

Soon moving to California he began working at McDonnell Douglas Aircraft where he maintained the gainly employment of a tube bender from 1967-1974. In 1968 he was divorced and went on to raise his kids as a single father until meeting Merdanstine and remarrying in 1974, They soon had a son together by the name of James Jr, combined with her four natural children. In 1977 he transferred jobs and began working at Northrop Aircraft Company. There he became a Master Mechanic and a tube bender until 1989. He would then go on and work for Boeing's Aircraft in Huntington Beach. He was a level 1 Supervisor in the production of the F-20 and the tubes on the C-17 Airlifter. He was the first black man to train other on the TQMS and the tube Fabricator becoming part of the Boeing 747 work crew later retiring from Aircraft work in 2002 giving 16 years of service.Â  After retiring he began working for Vance and Hines tube bender company until 2005. He then fully retired and moved to Las Vegas in 2018 to spend time with his children up until his departure from life.

item.title: Isaac Watson
item.description:
October 25, 1958 - January 9, 2022

Sunrise: October 25, 1958Â  Â  Â Sunset: January 9, 2022

"And God shall wipe away all tears from their eyes; and there shall be no more death, neither sorrow, nor crying. neither shall there be any more pain: for the former things are passed away" - Rev. 21:4

Isaac Donald Watson was born to the union of Elbert and Gracie Lee Ellen Moore Watson, on his mother's birthday, October 25, 1958, into a large family of brothers and sisters: Allen, William Kenneth, Robert Clifton, Timothy Peter, Geoffrey Christopher, Kristine, Jonie Mae, Margie Dianne, and Katheryn Yolanda. He grew up in Lynwood, California, and attended Lynwood High School, where he excelled in baseball, graduating in 1976. Upon graduating from high school, Isaac enlisted in the Marine Corps where he served as a chef. While serving in the Marine Corps, Isaac was introduced to the love of his life Pamela Edwards. They were united in holy matrimony on June 19, 1982. Staff Sergeant Isaac Donald Watson received his honorable discharge from the Marine Corps in 1984 and went to work with his father-in-law in his construction business. Always seeking to improve himself, "Donnie", as he was affectionately called by his family, also attended Cerritos College taking classes in drafting, animation. and computer coding. Isaac had an insatiable love for learning and continued keeping up on various topics by taking more classes, reading books, watching documentaries, and going to museums.Â 

On March 7, 1988, he and his wife Pam welcomes into the world their beautiful daughter Jennifer. She immediately became the center of their universe. Isaac was a devoted husband, father, and son. He became a caregiver for his wife Pam when she fell ill until her death on June 2, 2009, and subsequently helped to take care of his father when his health began to fail. In between time, because of his wife's illness, he sometimes became a stay-at-home dad to care for his daughter as well.Â 

Having served as a chef in the Marine Corps, it is no surprise that Donnie was a foodie, and loved to cook. He also liked taking long drives and watching movies. In addition, he enjoyed playing video games, and he loved playing card games. he was a huge football fan, and his favorite team was the Steelers.

Isaac enjoyed family activities, and many were the Saturday afternoons that he and his brother and sisters would find themselves at the park playing baseball.

Isaac was a gentle soul and loved his family. He and his brother Timothy were inseparable, and when Isaac became ill, he took over caring for him. He remained Isaac's devoted caregiver until the Lord called him home on the morning of January 9, 2022. "This is how we know what love is: Jesus Christ laid down his life for us. And we ought to lay down our lives for our brothers and sisters." - I John 3:16. Robert indeed exemplified this character quality in caring for his brother Isaac.

item.title: Hilary Cooper Jr.
item.description:
June 5, 1960 - December 29, 2021
Hilary Reed Cooper, age 61, loving father to six, and beloved partner to wife Earlena Cooper, passed away late afternoon Wednesday on December 29th 2021 after a courageous battle with gastric cancer. Hilary was born on June 5. 1960 in Monrovia Liberia, to the late Hilary Reed Cooper Sr. and late Annie Klorteh Nagbeh, he was later adopted and raised by his fraternal grandmother and great grandmother Arda V. Colling and Gertrude Thompson, after the passing of his father.
Â 
As a young boy he attended primary school in France learning to adapt tp new environments and becoming fluent in French. Hilary was an avid Soccer fan and player, loved listening o music and was an avid collector; there was nothing he loved more than being around family and friends. After he received his formal education in both Monrovia and Paris, he moved to Long Island, New York where he met his soon to be wife Earlena Cooper in 1984. They married a year later in which they traveled the world together raising four beautiful daughters over the span of 35 years. Kind, soft spoken, and a man of few words but his love for his family ran deep. There was no greater love for him than that of his family.Â 
As a young man, Hilary looked to better the life of his family and in 1988, he joined the United States Army and served with Honor and Distinction for 23 years to his adopted country of the United States of America. During his service as a United States Soldier he traveled extensively all over the world un support of military operations such as Operations Desert Storm, Operation Iraqi Freedom, Korean Defense, and the War on Terrorism. Hilary was a Purple Heart Recipient and a decorated soldier for his selflessness and contribution to his country, later on becoming a citizen of the United States. Although, he was proud of his Citizenship, he still had a longing and enduring love for his Country of Birth Liberia! Which he always spoke of returning to.

Hilary retired from the United States Army in August 2012 and later earning his Bachelor's degree in Business Administration. Hilary loved nothing more than his family and that goes especially for his grandchildren. He enjoyed the rest of his retirement in Hinesville, Georgia to be near his grandchildren and later on in Las Vegas, Nevada near two of his daughters who cherished the having him near. Hilary always put family first and more importantly he was a God Fearing man who believed in the power of prayer. He will be so very missed by those that loved and cared for him, but we are comforted in the fact that he suffers no more, and is at peace with God Almighty. Hilary was a loved by his family, and will be forever cherished for the man that he was, for his quiet strength, for being a beloved father, friend, and husband.

item.title: Magoliene Enyard
item.description:
December 31, 1951 - December 21, 2021

Sunrise: 12/31/1951Â  Â  Â Sunset: 12/19/2021

Magoliene Ward-Enyard was born December 31, 1951 in Pelahatchie, Mississippi to the parents of Maggie and Hosie Ward. She was the last child out of five children. Soon after her birth the family migrated to Los Angeles, California in search of a better life. Magoliene grew up in a warm loving home filled with family.

She attended Kindergarten to 6th grade at Lincoln Elementary, 7th - 9th grade at Ralph Bunch Jr. High School, 10th - 12th grade at Centennial Sr. High School, where she was known for her performances in the school talent shows, as well as cheering with the Centenettes. her love for music began early on, as her mother and father would always encourage their babies to sing. They purchased a family piano that their children amd friends gathered around on Sundays to sing songs. Magoliene was known for her kindred spirit. As a teenager she would look forward to spending her summers taking care of her niece and nephews. As an adult she unselfishly spent most of her time assisting her mother and taking care of loved ones who had taken ill. so it was to no surprise that Magoliene would pursue a career in the medical field.

Soon after high school, Magoliene attended the Bryman Institute, graduating with duo certificates as a CNS and a medical assistant. She earned her first job at Athens Park Hospital as a CNA in Los Angeles, California. For several years, she worked for Dr. Mosely, until she has to abruptly stop working to care for her parents who had taken ill.

In the late 1970's, Magoliene met and married Cecil John Enyard in a beautiful front yard wedding that she'd planned and decorated from beginning to end. Magoliene knew how to throw a party, from flowers, furs, feathers, etc. If it was over the top, it was Mag (as she was affectionately known by close friends and family). Being the power couple of their time, Magoliene and Cecil became proud young black business owners of The Sound Boutique, which was located in Compton, California. The Sound Boutique would become 1 of the three businesses that she owned and operated.

In the 1990's, Magoliene pursued a career in education, becoming a Parent-Teacher Facilitator for the Los Angeles School District. Which bridged the gap between parents and teachers, by creating necessary relationships for the interest of the children. She was praised by her administrators as well as the parents for her outstanding leadership.

Soon after her death of her first born son, Larry Haynes, Magoliene moved to Las Vegas where she would make her home enjoying her grandchildren and great grand children until she was called home on December 19, 2021.

Tamika was educated in Altadena and Pasadena, California. She attended Burbank Elementary School, Jackson Elementary, Wilson Middle School and Marshall Fundamental School.

Tamika was a proud devoted mother of 3 boys, Trevion being her oldest, then Malik and lastly Deion. She had Malik and Deion after she relocated to Las Vegas with her mother, always known as her twin.

Tamika was such a sweet and happy person. She was quiet and stayed to herself, but she has a smile that would brighten your day and a warming laugh which made her such a great person to be around.

Tamika had a love for music. She would go on YouTube and watch the same songs over and over and just bob her head and smile. Some of her favorite artists were, Lloyd, Ludacris, Snoop Dogg, John Legend, Amanda Perez, Chris Brown, and more. She was a huge fan of Ice Cube because he reminded her so much of her brother, Michael, Jr. Tamika loved watching movies but would never leave the house to go see any. Everyone knew that about her. Some of her favorite were: Boys in the Hood, You got Served, and Stomp the Yard, just to name a few.Â 

If you knew Tamika, you knew that he loved any and all kinds of food, with seafood being her favorite. She was ready and willing to try it all. Tavion was always bringing her whatever he was eating. She also enjoyed the drinks that he would bring her from Fat Tuesday. Throughout it all, the bond that she shared with her 3 boys was unbreakable.

item.title: John Vaughn
item.description:
November 7, 1975 - December 13, 2021
John Edward Vuaghn Jr. enters the fates of heaven on December 13. 2021, at the age of forty-six. He was born in Detroit, MI, the youngest of two children to John Edward (who proceeded him in death) and Betty Vaughn Sr. He was a jovial child who often made his family laugh with his cute sayings, silly jokes and harmonica playing. John loved to talk. Growing up his sister would often bet him five dollars to be quiet for just one hour/ John always lost.Â 

John was diagnosed with Sickle Cell Anemia Disease when he was two years old, however that never stopped his shine or ambition. he was a good student. graduating with honors from Redford High School in 1993. John was a hard worker. He always had a side hustle. Often stating, "If it don't make dollars, it don't make sense!" After high school he worked various positions before serving as a Certified Nursing Assistant at Hospice of Michigan for ten years. The families he served loved him! In 2006, he enrolled at Specs Howard School of Broadcast Arts, gaining a passion for audio-video engineering. That decision impacted his life tremendously.

In 2007, he founded and became CEO of his own company Not Your Battle Productions. he did well in Detroit but knew he could do even better if he relocated his family to Henderson, NV. There he quickly gained experience and knowledge in the entertainment industry leading to a production position for the famous Michael Jackson or MJ1 show and later and audio-video engineering supervisor at the T-Mobile arena. John's colleagues often became his close friends consistently spoke highly of him as a professional and an upstanding person anyone would enjoy meeting and getting to know.

John accepted Christ at an early age, attending Christian Community Baptist Church in Detroit, MI. There he participated in numerous auxiliaries throughout his life, such as the youth choir and audio ministry. Upon his relocation to Henderson, NV, he with his family, joined Life Springs Christian Church in Las Vegas, NV. He was also a part of the audio-video ministry there. Everyone at both churches loved John's jubilant personality.

John truly did love life and live it well! His radiant energy would fill a room and permeate the hearts of everyone who knew him. His children meant the world to him. He was an outstanding father.

item.title: Stephen Ray Hankins
item.description:
January 20, 1974 - August 6, 2021
The Life Of Stephen Ray " Steve " Hankins

ï»¿Stephen Ray Hankins was born in Las Vegas, NV on January 20, 1974, to Bettie Hankins and Willie Slocum. Stephen Accepted Christ at an early age at Pilgrim Rest Missionary Baptist Church. In his adulthood, Stephen became a member of St. James Missionary Baptist Church. Stephen attended and graduated from Vo-Tech High School in 1992. He then went on to trade school in Phoenix, AZ for welding. Stephen was dedicated to his career as a Blackflow Technician with the Las Vegas Valley Water District for over 18 years.
Stephen was a family man. He loved his family more than anything in the world. He enjoyed spending time with his family and always tried to make time for those closet to him. If you ever asked those whom he spent his time with, "who was his best friend'? Everyone would give you the same answer: "I was Stephen's Bestfriend!" Stephen valued his relationships. He made his loved ones feel special and important. Stephen was a protector and a very caring person. He would always assure that everyone he loved was taken care of, even if it meant making personal sacrifices. Stephen enjoyed watching sports.
Football season was his favorite. When the Steelers were playing, he was not to be bothered. Losing Stephen is a great loss to his family and loved ones. He will be greatly missed, and he has taken a piece of us with him.

item.title: Rodney Tisdell II
item.description:
June 23, 1988 - August 2, 2021
Rodney Garette Tisdell, II
AKA Doobie

Doobie was born to Carolyn Landers and Rodney Garette Tisdell in Las Vegas, NV. Doobie attended Madison E.S., Francis H. Cortney Middle School, Cimmaron Memorial High School. He then continued his education as a phlebotomist. Shortly after he discovered his true passion of hair styling. Doobie could do some hair! He was great at that. He took his craft to the next level becoming a master loctician. Acquiring well over 100 clients. He brought the North into the West!
Doobie enjoyed playing outside with a host of cousins and friends. Doobie loved playing video games. He played basketball in the neighborhood. He loved watching anything related to vampires, witches and warlocks. He was often found sitting in the kitchen watching his auntie cook. Doobie could cook, too! He loved being around his family. He would ride bikes from family members house to family member's house. As he grew up, he took pleasure in babysitting his younger cousins and doing their hair. He graduated from creating styles on them to a professional level.
Rodney elevated to Doobie then "Lit by Doobie" to his signature brand, "Sit and Get Lit". His sit andÂ  get lit ignited all over the city. "Lit by Doobie" was profitable and was FIRE at Mary Crystylez. When Doobie wasn't working as a locologist, he was on "River" hanging with the crew. The crew was more than just hanging out; they genuinely tried motivating and pushing each other to do better and be better. They loved having fun laughing, singing, and bagging on each other. Doobie enjoyed all kinds of music from rock and roll, rap, R&B and even country. He was the stylist to 31 Flavours Drill Team and pretty much everyone, really.
Ain't no way you would go out with Doobie if your edges weren't laid, if your socks did not match didn't match, if your strips didn't match your polka dots, if your colors didn't coordinate or if you needed a girdle. Doobie was always going to tell you the REAL! He was always a real person. He would tell you if you were wrong to your face. He would tell you and build you up.Â  He wanted the best for the women that were in his life. Even if it meant holding himself to the same standard. He himself was transformed from the person he used to be to the person he became. Over these last 2 months he was more loving, kind and more forgiving.Â  He was the most generous he has ever been and everybody around him noticed. He loved his dogs, Queen and Cleo. He grew a passion for growing his plants and his cars.
He was the most generous he has ever been and everybody around was an entrepreneur, a father, a loyal friend, dependable family member, a business owner and an ultimate motivator.
Doobie's light shined so bright that when he walked in the room, he commanded everyone's attention. Whether it was throwing out a joke, the way he was impeccably dressed or just his 1000-watt smile. All eyes on him.
]]>

item.title: Billy Sherman Hicks III
item.description:
January 8, 1982 - July 7, 2021
Obituary

Billy Sherman Hicks III, 39,Â  born January 8th, 1982, at Dominguez Valley Hospital in Long Beach California. Billy grew up in the LA region, stemming from LA to Compton to Watts in his early years. Billy grew up in church, home to Abundant Joy Christian Fellowship now known as the dwelling place where he was baptized and accepted Jesus as his Lord and Savior. Billy had such a reverence for the Lord. Growing up in church Billy played different roles as an usher and also working behind the scenes as a camera man during church service every Sunday. Billy would also travel to downtown LA with his family as they prayed for and fed those that were less fortunate. Billy had a big heart and was extremely passionate for those in need. Another passion he had was the love of sports and was highly involved in his childhood years. Billy was an outstanding baseball player, formally nicknamed "The clean up batter" but also had a huge affinity for basketball and football as well. Will Rodgers Park is where his love for sport kicked off as Billy played all year around for a decade and receiving many accolades during that time frame.
Billy moved to Buena Park and attended Western Highschool in Anaheim California where he made many friends that he continued to have close relationships with all the way up to his passing. Billy joined the football team as a freshman and worked his way up to varsity level as a senior. Along with playing football, Billy enjoyed watching football leisurely and was a huge Dallas Cowboy fan. After graduating high school, Billy attended San Diego Job Corp where he received a certification in business as he looked to pursue a career as an accountant. Billy also attended Nevada State School of massage therapy in 2017 and eventually took on the role of a massage therapist. Soon after, he went on to pursue a career in the food and restaurant business where he excelled. Other hobbies Billy loved was listening to music, cooking and being around the people he loved especially his kids. Billy was a great father! Gave all he had and would always shower them with love. Billy passed away peacefully from this life into eternal life on Sunday July 18th, 2021, at North Vista Hospital in Henderson Nevada. His caring heart, laid back demeanor, sweet spirit and love for family will truly be missed
]]>

item.title: Pamela Emma Hawkins-Kulshrestha
item.description:
October 16, 1950 - July 3, 2021

Pamela Hawkins Kulshrestha

October 16, 1950

July 3, 2021

Pamela Emma Hawkins-Kulshrestha a wife, mother, grandmother, great grandmother, sibling and friend to many, departed this life the morning of Saturday July 3, 2021 after a lengthy illness. She was born to the late John Henry Bolden Seaman 2nd CL U.S. Navy of Fowlstown Ga. January 15, 1890 â August 6, 1965 and Adeline Nellie Coleman, Doman, Bolden (affectionately known as Helen) May 21, 1918 â April 27, 1970 on October 16, 1950 in Olean, NY at St. Francis Hospital. She attended Olean School #4, Buffalo East H.S. where she obtained her high school diploma, and Erie Community College where she obtained her AAS diploma. During her life she had numerous accomplishments.

She obtained civil service employment with the Buffalo Board of Education as a senior clerk, from which she retired after 30+ years of service to her final home of Las Vegas Nevada where she resided until her death.Â She accepted Christ at an early age at Pentecostal Temple C.O.G.I.C. under her cousin the late Bishop Charles Henry McCoy. She attended other churches after his passing, Deliverance Temple (COGIC), Prayer Tower, and the Salvation Army. Pamela was well known and a very respected member of her community. She was a joyful person to be around, quick-witted and playful. Many Friends and loved ones who had the pleasure of knowing Pamela were fortunate to have her play the role of a protector, a friend, one who loved deeply, and a warrior for those who could not fight for themselves.

She will be greatly missed by all, at social gatherings, especially those family oriented. As a child Pam loved animals, dogs, birds, tadpoles, and minnows that she encountered in Olean. She made life long friendships with the Gaytons, and Gilberts.Â She was married twice in her lifetime to the late Wade Hawkins and Pankaj kulshrestha. She was part of a very large family of Boldenâs.

She leaves to cherish her memory: her late grand parents: Mary Emma Bolden and Calvin (Cabe) Bolden and Mary Ellen Coleman Walker, her siblings: the late Rebecca Hill Sherrell (late Calvin Sherrell), the late Rhoda Celestine Doman Brooks (late Lee Wesley Brooks), Charles Doman, the late Sidney Doman, the late Leo John Bolden, Mary June Bolden Coleman, Maureen Lily Bolden Odusanya Hill (late Dapo Odusanya, and Edward Dixon Hill), Calvin Bolden; 3 devoted sons John Bolden, Alonzo (Allicia) Bolden, Pierre (Barbara) Bolden; 1 doting daughter Ericka (DaRahn) Rainey, 14 affectionate grandchildren; Briana (John Jr.) Norman, Jasmine Frazier, Alonzo Bolden Jr., DaRahn Rainey Jr., Erick Rainey, Da'Naeya Rainey, Amon Bolden, Anthony Rainey, Isabella Bolden, Nia Rainey, Sophia Bolden, Isaiah Rainey, and Gabriella Bolden. 5 Great grandchildren; Ariana Norman, Messiah Shaver, DaRahn Rainey III, John Norman III, and Ava Norman. item.title: Michael Edward Meagher
item.description:
October 31, 1950 - December 20, 2021

MichaelÂ Edward Meagher 70, of N. Las Vegas, NV, passed away Sun, Dec. 20, 2020 of Covid. Born Oct. 31, 1950 in Middletown, CT to Robert John Meagher and Laura Grasso Meagher. Preceded in death by his parents; grandson Taylor Beahm and sister, Loretta Kenney-Nassif. MichaelÂ is survived by his best friend and love of over 27 years, Christine Meagher; his step-mothers Josephine Brinkmann and Dixie Sylvester; his kids; Robert Meagher, Christopher (Cara) Meagher, and Timothy Meagher with their mother KarryLu Carpenter. Chaz (Stacey) de Jonge, Christie (Brandon) Dorsey and Jessica (Matt) Padgett. Grandchildren; Breanna, Arthur, Mikah, Jakob, Blake, Brayden D, Asher, Zayne, Chloe, Paige, Kailey and Brayden P. His siblings; Mary, Patti and Barbi.
ââAunt Ging, family, students and friends. MichaelÂ moved to Las Vegas at the age of five. Graduated from Las Vegas High School in 1969. He was a veteran of the U.S. Navy in the Vietnam War.Â Receiving his Bachelor of Fine Arts degree at UNLV in 1975 and started his freelance photography business âPhotographs by Michaelâ. He started teaching in 1976 and in 1987 he went full time teaching Photo & Digital Technologies at the College of Southern Nevada.
He was a member of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. MichaelÂ and Christine married July 17, 1993 and in 1995 were sealed in the Las Vegas Temple. item.title: Irissa Lakes
item.description:
April 4, 1943 - May 18, 2021
A Look into the Life of...
Irissa H. Lakes

Irissa H. Lakes was the oldest of 10 children born to the late Ernestine and Arthur Jones on April 4, 1943 in Chicago Illinois. Irissa gave her life to Christ at an early age where she attended the Mt. Calvary Baptist Church in Chicago Illinois; later serving there on the usher board with her late husband, Ozzie Lakes.

Irissa was raised in the Morgan Park area where she attended the John D. Shoop Elementary School and the Morgan Park High School both in the Chicagoland area. Irissa had many nicknames: Reese, Reese Cup, The Warden and more recently affectionately called Chickey by her son-in-law, Nate; but the greatest names to her were mother or Momma called her by her 5 children. She raised or help to raise grandchildren, great grandchildren, nieces, nephews, 3 foster children and many others---all of whom adored her. Irissa was so loved and gave so much love!

Anyone would tell you that Irissa was one of the hardest working women you would ever meet; sometimes taking on two jobs while raising her 5 children. Her work experience as an order filler at Crodar Inc. for 20 years and a waitress at Steak and Eggs for 15 years---not to mention being the oldest of 10 siblings brought great responsibility, all of which contributed to her great work ethics...her life experiences were being nourished all along the way. And, because she never let anything interfere with what God had in store for her; Irissa became an entrepreneur, the proud owner of L&L Soul Food in Roseland Illinois for 7 years.

One of the more memorable times for Irissa was being with her 12 talented siblings (they all either sang and/or danced) gathering at the Roots Community Picnic for a great time to be had by all in the community. Her never-wavering faith in God carried her through her illnesses...when the doctors marked her time she trusted in the Lord, knowing that He is the author and finisher of her earthly life until her new resurrected forever life with Him.

]]>

item.title: Rodney A. Jones
item.description:
November 24, 1944 - March 24, 2021
Viewing

April Friday 9, 2021
10:00am-11:00am

Service
April Friday 9, 2021
11:00am-12:00pm

Obituary

On the great day of November 24, 1944, Rodney Allen Jones was born to the parents of Launice Katherine Bush and Carey Ardell Jones of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Rodney was the sixth oldest of 14 children. His mother would remarry and Rodney would be raised by both his mother and stepfather Percy Lee Cummings, where he would grow up in New Castle, Pennsylvania. Rodney attended New Castle Senior High School in New Castle PA where he played sports. While he loved all sports, his favorites to play were baseball and basketball, Rodney was the star player on his high school team. After high school, he would then join the Military. He served in the Navy for a couple of years where he worked on a fleet tub. He would recover those who perished at sea. Being in the military had its positives and negatives. Positives you get to travel around the world and see many different places. Rodney had a chance to go to Vietnam he would fight in the Vietnam War. The negative side of the military that one would see so many tragedies that could have long-term effects. Rodney couldn't bear to see any more tragedies. So he would be honorably discharged after serving two and a half years. After the military, he would move to Boston where he lived there for several years. He didn't care much for Boston so he moved out west to Los Angeles. While in LA he worked as a short-order cook at Hamburger Hamlet to get on his feet. He then started painting, he painted residential and commercial buildings throughout the city of Los Angeles.Â 

In his spare time, he would play in different bands and nightclubs around the city. Rodney loved to play the conga drums and the tambourine. While performing one night he would meet his future wife, Sandra Winfrey, they would move to her hometown of San Francisco, CA. They would get married in 1981 in Reno, NV. After they got married they were on a journey to start their life together. Sandra worked for the San Francisco Unified School District as an Administrative Assistant for Student Nutrition Services. Sandra would then help Rodney get his foot in the door where he would work in food services until retirement in 2005. Alongside working in the school district Rodney would volunteer and coach Junior Varsity basketball at several different junior high and high schools in the San Francisco area. In 1982 Rodney and Sandra would welcome their first child together Jasmine Jones. Jasmine was the apple of Rodney's eye. He loved everything about being a father/ #GirlDad Growing up he would teach Jasmine how to play different instruments, he enjoyed taking her and the neighborhood kids to the park, music festivals, sporting events, even work sometimes, and so much more.Â 

The two were inseparable until Jasmine went off to college. Once she graduated and came back home the two would pick up where they left off, traveling and hanging out and creating memories. After retirement Rodney could not sit still he started working at Candlestick Park. He continued on the path of nutrition he worked the concession stands during the SF Giants, and 49ers games. He enjoyed doing that because he got to meet so many different people from different walks of life, Rodney met no strangers. Later he would then part ways with Candlestick Park and in 2010 he and Sandra would become grandparents to their first and only grandchild, Chance Herring. He adored Chance and would spend the majority of his time with Chance taking him to the park, or for ice cream or sharing with him one of his many stories and much more. When Jasmine and Chance decided to move to Las Vegas 2013, Rodney was not going to be that far behind. He and his grandson were truly inseparable; he wanted to be near Chance so he could spend as much time with him, make even more memories and to watch him grow. Although his heart was in San Francisco, Rodney also had his two sisters living in Las Vegas at the time, he enjoyed being around family so this made the move a little bit easier. Other than spending time with his grandson he would love to play dominoes, bid whist, chess, read the news paper, work crossword puzzles, listen to music especially Jazz, he enjoyed watching westerns, he loved watching his sports especially his San Francisco sport teams The Warriors, The 49ers and The Giants.

Â He would even watch reruns if season was over. Most important he loved to be around family and friends. Although, no longer serving in the military, it was like Rodney was constantly at war with his health and life situations. Rodneyâs health was slowly deteriorating over the years but he didnât let that stop him from getting around. In 1996 he was diagnosed with Lung Cancer; it was detected early so he was able to make a full recovery. A few years later he had a hip replacement, and in 2005 he had a second hip replacement. In 2014 his wife of 33 years passed away to Lung Cancer. In 2015 Rodney was diagnosed with Prostate Cancer and had to go through Chemotherapy. In 2016, he beat and made a full recovery from Prostate Cancer. In 2018 Rodney's hip needed to be replaced again, and this time around the doctors said his hip was in such bad condition that it was a miracle he was even walking. In early 2019 Rodney lost a sister, later that year his stepson died in a plane crash over the Pacific Ocean. In 2020 he would battle with Covid, on March 24, 2021, due to complications of Covid and other underline health issues Rodney would bow out gracefully. During his last week, he built up enough strength to talk to friends and family near and far. He had a heart of gold. no matter how much suffering and pain he went through he wanted you to know he was going to be alright. His spirit was that of a Warrior and will forever be in our hearts.Â 

Preceded in Rodneyâs death were his wife, Sandra O. Winfrey-Jones, and stepson Justin Winfrey. His parents, Launice K. Cummings, Percy L.Cummings, Carey Jones. Three sisters and two brothers, Denise Cummings, Dianne Harvey, and Debra Jefferson, Arthur "Red" Jones, and Maxwealth Ra. Rodney leaves to celebrate his life and cherish his fond memories, his daughter Jasmine Jones-Herring (Brandon) of Las Vegas. He leaves his precious imprint on his grandson Chance I. Herring of Las Vegas. One brother Jeffrey Cummings (Monica) of Lancaster, CA. Six sisters Patricia Jones (Las Vegas), Donna Hargrave (Las Vegas), Saundra McCarter (Reseda, CA), and Launice Cummings (Lancaster, CA). Rodney leaves behind a host of nieces and nephews and many family and friends from around the world to honor and cherish his memory.

Â 

Acknowledgements

Â The family of Rodney A. Jones wishes to express its profound thanks to each of you for your kindness. Perhaps you sent flowers or made us a meal. Perhaps you sent a lovely card or maybe we saw you there. Perhaps you spoke the kindest words that any friend could say. Perhaps you were not there at all but thought and prayed for us that day. Your thoughtfulness has meant so much and everything you have done is truly appreciated. A warm thank you to the Staff at Royal Springs Healthcare, Mountain View Hospital, Nathan Adelson Hospice Care, Serenity Funeral Home, and Pastor Naida Parsons and to friends and family near and far, we THANK YOU!


]]>

item.title: Joyce Marie Valmore
item.description:
December 28, 1946 - March 14, 2021
Joyce Marie Valmore passed away on March 14,2021 at the age of 74. Born in Lake Village, Arkansas, Joyce (referred to as 'Ree" by her siblings) moved to Las Vegas, Nevada in her early teens, and has resided there ever since . Joyce graduated from Western High School in it's second graduating class. She was a longtime employee of the Clark County School District, and was actually the longest tenured employee at the time of her passing. Over the years, she built numerous lasting relationships with coworkers at William Orr, Jr. High, Lois Craig, Mountain View, and J.M. Ullom Elementary Schools.Â 

A bit of a workaholic, Joyce took pride in helping the staff at her school do the best work that they could. She even made it a priority to try get payroll out in her final days...that's dedication! Beside working, Joyce loved to cook, and try different foods, and work in her garden. Her Love for fishing might have been her greatest passion; Joyce would be willing to cast out her rod at the drop of a dime no matter if it was hot, cold, or even in a thunderstorm (except when the lightning comes...but that's another story). She beamed with pride at the mention of her grandkids, as they were her pride and joy.

Joyce was always know for making other people smile, and offering words of encouragement whenever she could lend a hand. Known for her generosity, she would often cook meals for those who were sick, or provide financial help to those in need when she could. She has touched many lives within her lifespan, and has definitely made the world a better place. Raising three son on her own was daunting task, however, she excelled at it became the best mom EVER!!!
]]>

October of 2011 with the opening of the new church "Temple of Love" of the first Samoan Full Gospel Pentecostal Church under the leadership of Rev Tugalue Tau their spiritual walk continued as Folafola/Deacon. They then rejoined Rev. Sula to continue their spiritual Journey.

Dad went to be with our Lord Jesus Christ <March of 2013. Mom continue her spiritual walk in Las Vegas, NV with "Temple of Love" of the first Samoan Full Gospel Pentecostal Church under the leadership of Rev. Tugalue Tau until February 9, 2021 when she made her entrance into that beautiful city. Mom was prepared and ready for that day. Her fear of the Lord made her the beautiful strong woman she was to each of us.Â 
Put God first, regardless of the trials you face. Love God.

Have faith in Christ and entrust yourself to him in all things- that was our Mother.
Our Mama, Her smile brightens our everyday, her kind words warmth our hearts, her hugs made us feel safe, her caring personality always made us, and others feel welcome. Our mother was one-of-kind person who stayed ready to help in any way she can. Her heart was made of gold. Her love for our Lord Jesus Christ made her that amazing mother to everyone. She always put God first in everything she did.

item.title: Meah Dewana Boyd

Meah "Mimi" Boyd was born November 28, 1977 in Tucson, Arizona to Faith Gaines. The middle child of three daughters born to Faith, Mimi (as she was affectionately called) spent her early years and young adult life between her hometown and California. In 1996, Mimi graduated from Woodrow Wilson Classical High School in Long Beach, California. During her time in Long Beach, Mimi's union with her high school sweetheart Jason Jones produced two precious sons: Trevion and Larry, The two remained friends and co-parent throughout her life, In Long Beach, Mimi's mother found everlasting love when she married Floyd, whom Mimi came to consider her father, no "step" title included.

Mimi went on to Marry Roosevelt Marshall Jefferson, and together they welcomed two beautiful daughters: Malaysia and Nautica. Mimi studied multiple subjects in the medical field, obtaining various certifications throughout the years. Mimi eventually moved to Las Vegas, Nevada with her children where she lived out the rest of her life. During her time in Vegas Mimi formed a loving, lifelong friendship with Tay, who will forever be known as family. Those that knew Mimi were blessed to experience such a true, authentic and unforgettable soul.

Â Yet her realness only complimented the true beauty she was, both inside and out. She had a smile that lit up a room and a laugh that could lighten anyone's spirit, no matter the mood. Her energy was contagious, and it didn't take long for her to turn new connections into lifelong, memorable relationships.

Cooking and music were passions shared withÂ  both friends and family. She hoped to finish her education at Liberty University and use her degree to serve the Lord.

Charles (Chuck) August Wojciechowski, age 60, passed away in Las Vegas, NV on Wednesday, February 17, Â  2021 after a brave battle with cancer. He was born June 2, 1960 in Baltimore, MD where he resided until relocating with his family and company to Las Vegas, NV in January of 2000. Chuck was an avid hiker who loved the outdoors and would often camp-out in the desert under the stars. He also enjoyed paddle boarding, mountain biking, scuba diving, skiing, woodworking, terrain races, and spending time with his family. Chuck is survived by his daughter, Nicole Wojciechowski of Austin, TX, his son, Cory Wojciechowski of Las Vegas, NV, former wife Mary Jo Wojciechowski of Las Vegas, NV, his brothers Stephen and Raymond of Maryland, sister Rose of Pennsylvania, and was preceded in death by his sister Maria of Maryland. Chuckâs wishes are for his ashes to be spread in the mountains of Mt. Charleston, NV and at the beach in Ocean City, MD so that he may rest in eternal peace in the great outdoors.Â 

His family will be honoring him with a Celebration of Life ceremonies to be held both in Nevada and Maryland at future dates to be announced.

item.title: Clyde Watkins
item.description:
April 4, 1933 - January 24, 2021
He was a long time resident of Las Vegas, Nevada since 1944. Clyde was a sport enthusiast he was nicknamed " Rabbit" because of his speed in running. In his early years he participated in such sports as basketball, boxing, and track and field. At the early age of 14 he was known in the community for his skills as a pool player. He reportedly traveled the states participating as a pool player and won many Championships and trophies. Clyde started working at an early age of 13 as a dishwasher at the Flamingo Hotel. He later became a prep chef, later he moved to the Dunes Hotel where he worked as a Pullman.
His final job was at the Caesar Palace Hotel in 1966 he worked again as a Pullman and later as a Bellman. Clyde was well known in the West Las Vegas Community as well as atÂ  Caesar Palace Hotel. Through his job and involvement in the community, "Rabbit" as he was referred to, was well known by many top entertainers, boxing greats, and had many friends. He retired from CaesarÂ 
Palace Hotel after 45 years of service. Clyde loved his family and has had a positive influence in the lives of his family, friends, and acquaintances. Clyde "Rabbit" Watkins will be greatly missed.Â

As life continued she grew a passion for food and went to school where cooking became her hobby. During Chantra's battle with cancer her love for foodÂ  never faded and she began joining different cooking groups online where she would cook food live for people. item.title: David Andrew Foster
item.description:
January 8, 1962 - December 30,2020
Celebration of Life - David Andrew Foster was born on January 8, 1962, in Chicago, Illinois tp Mother -Barbara Ann Faster and Father-Gene. David was the fourth of six siblings, there are three boys, and two girls, all of whom are still living in this present day. When David was a little boy, he wouldÂ  be the first one up in the mornings, fully dressed ready for his adventures for the day. Among all of his siblings, we all used to watch Saturday morning Bugs Bunny Cartoons in which we all got nicknames from the characters and David's nickname Tweety Bird because he got up early in the morning like the birds and he favored the cartoon character Tweety Bird from the Bugs Bunny Cartoons so we gave him that name and that's what family and friends called him until his departure from this earth. We were a fun-loving musical family and we all love to dance and sing.
David sure could dance, he would sit you down doing the James Brown when we were in talent shows when he was a little boy and family gatherings. David also loved to beat Drums, that was his passion. He loved listening to music and singing along with lyrics.
David was diagnosed with TBI (Traumatic Brain Injury) from an incident that occurred when he was 15 years old, after his stay in the hospital, he had to learn all of our names, learn how to walk and talk all over again. From that point, with his health issues for many, many years he would always manage to give you a smile. He tried his best to live a normal life, going to various places on his own, working part-time when he could. David graduated from grammar school and high school.
As he got older, his health started failing to the point, he could no longer care for himself and to be placed in Assisted Facilities with 24-hour medical care. As his days were nearing, he still would manage to wave and smile at you. David loved the Lord and was at peace with his relationship with our heavenly father.
David touched so many people's hearts and will truly be missed, he will forever leaves his impact and love on each and every one of us who knew and grew to love him dearly. David departed from our lives on December 30, 2020.Â 
]]>

Sus padres Jose Leon y Margarita Tobar que ya pasaron el Senor tambien, siendo un total de cuatro hermanos. Damos gracias a nuestro Dios por su vida y su arduo trabajo en la obra de Dios; dando el no solo testimonio de su Fe, si no tambien predicando con su ejemplo de fidelidad al Senor.

Su jornada en este mundo ya termino, pero el ya no tendra mas dolor, ni sufrimiento pues a pasado de muerte a vida, y descansa en los brazos del Senor. A nuestro Dios le placio llevarlo en tiempo como este; recordemos su carino, amor y su fidelidad a nuestro Dios.

item.title: Ronald Ricardo Dines
item.description:
December 30, 1959 - October 3, 2020
Ronald was born December 30, 1959 to Adline Clement of Leesville, LA., who predeceased him June of 1960. Following the death of his mother at only six months old, Ronald and his twin Donald were raised by their grandparent's, Emma and John Johnson, both deceased. Ronald confessed his faith in Jesus Christ at an early age and was baptized in St. Paul Baptist Church Answering the family call, his aunt Doris and her husband Edward Dines, deceased, adopted Ronald and Donald, in 1973, bringing them into their family in Portland, Oregon.

Ronald attended elementary elementary school in Leesville, LA., and high school in Portland, Oregon. Ronald met his first wife Rhonda Syth, now deceased, while attending Grant High School, Portland Oregon, and the two were married after he graduated. To this union his, Dontae was born. Ronald entered the United States Army in 1977 and later served in the Army Reserve. Ronald was honorably discharged in 1983.

After the dissolution of this marriage, Ronald and his son Dontae relocated to Las Vegs, Nevada. Here he met and married Rhonda fields. T this Union two Children were born, Ryan and Ashley Dines.
Consistent with his compassionate caring nature, after receiving his CNA license, He pursued a career in health care working in nursing Homes and Home Health care Agencies, caring mainly for the elderly, until his health failed. Even so, whatever help he could give, Ronald gave cheerfully and from his heart. Ronald loved his family passionately, his own as well as his extended family.
His family could also, on any given day, witness his feeding the homeless around him and many times sheltering them as well. Ronald's heart was big for all people but especially for those who had less than himself. We are all suffering a profound loss at the passing of Ronald, who was loved dearly. But we know that while he is absent in the body, he is now present with the Lord, ref. 2nd Cor. 5:8.
]]>
