item.title: Gloria Karlene Allen
item.description:
February 17, 1944 - December 05, 2020Â 
Gloria Karlene Allen was born in the Northern California Bay Area in Oakland, California on 17 February 1944 to Karl and Iona Dolly Heinemann. Gloria was raised and grew up in Oakland, California until she finished High School and started business school. She was introduced by her best friend to her husband Robert D. Allen - doctorate student at UCLA in Los Angeles, California. Gloria and Robert married in August 1965 in Oakland, California.

Gloria and Robert lived in different places due to Robert's science research work. After they married, Gloria and her husband lived husband lived in Los Angeles, California. While inÂ  Los Angeles, Gloria was introduced to the Baha'i Faith by Native American Sand Painting Artist - David Villasenor. Gloria and Robert then moved to Vancouver, Canada. After a year they then moved to Indiana, then decided to move to Morgantown, West Virginia to work for West Virginia University. While in Morgantown, Gloria became increasingly active in the Baha' I Faith serving on theÂ  local spiritual assembly and a national committee.Â 

Gloria attended a Baha'I conference and was told by a Baha' I Hand of the cause to go to school to study the Russian language so she could teach people in Russia about the Baha'I Faith. Gloria enrolled at West Virginia University (WVU), completed her studies and obtained her Bachelors' degree of Liberal Arts in the Russian language in August 1979. During the early years of her studies, she took her first international trip to Russia as part of her studies, where she also had the opportunity to visit England, France and Holland.
While studying for her Bachelors' degree she had two sons - Ryan born January 1977, then Kevin born August 1978. Due to jobs in Academics, Gloria and Robert continued to move with their two sons throughout the USA, living for some time in Ohio and Minnesota, then returned to Southern California until her son finished High School. Gloria continued to serve on local Baha'I assemblies in Ohio and California.

While living in California raising her teenage sons, Gloria found she had breast cancer. Her doctor operated and was able to remove the cancer making her a breast cancer survivor. It was also during these years in California, Gloria traveled for her Baha'I pilgrimage to the Baha'I holy land in Haifa, Israel. Gloria enjoyed working for a elementary school in Apple Valley, California as an office assistant.
After Gloria's youngest son, Kevin, finished high school and moved to Las Vegas to attend UNLV, Gloria and Robert moved to northern California, where Gloria worked at Bosch Baha'I school as an office assistant. Gloria and Robert then decided to move to Las Vegas, NV to be closer to their son Kevin, where Gloria resided until she passed. During her last twenty years in Las Vegas, Gloria found she once again had breast cancer and her doctor was again able to do the surgery to remove the cancer, making her a breast cancer survivor twice. Gloria continued to be active in local Las Vegas Baha'I communities, continued to serve on local Baha'I assemblies and teach youth classes.

Gloria loved to travel internationally and explore many exotic destinations around the world. While her son Kevin studied in France, Gloria enjoyed exploring the city of Paris spending much time in the Louvre and Orsay art museums. Also, during her time in Las Vegas, due to her and her families love of travel, Gloria and her family opened up a travel business specializing, in cruise ship travel from 2006 until 2014. During this time Gloria and her family enjoyed much international travel going to world destinations including India, Europe, Africa, Caribbean, Mexico, Panama and Alaska. One of her favorite trips was to India where she got to visit the Baha'I House of Worship in Delhi, India.Â 

Gloria's other favorite InternationalÂ  trip was to visit her bestfriend and "heart sister"- Apollonia, in Tanzania, Africa, where she took ten days on a Africa Safari. Gloria loved to watch the animals in the Tanzanian national parks. Gloria is survived by her husband, Robert Allen and two sons - Ryan and Kevin. Gloria's friends have quoted the following about her - "she was always such a lovely soul as she walked this earth", "she was always such a beautiful example of loving kindness" and "Gloria was a rose whose flower kept my spirit alive".
]]>

item.title: James E. Brown
item.description:
December 2, 1941 - November 21, 2020ï»¿
James Edward Brown (affectionately known as J.B.) was born December 2, 1941 in Richmond, Virginia to James and Addie Brown ( both whom preceded him in death). J.B. graduated from Armstrong High school in 1960 and soon thereafter enlisted into the United States Air Force, earning an Associated Degree in Avionics Technology. His enlistment with the Air Force resulted in him serving two tours in Vietnam. He furthered his education by attending Georgia Military College, Chaffey Community College, Regents College and California State University Long Beach.

After serving his country for 26 1/2 years, J.B. retired from the Air Force in 1987 from Castle Air Force Base in Merced, California with the prestigious title of Senior Master Sargent. He then found employment with Douglas Aircraft Company (Boeing) with the positions of a level 5 senior Manufacturing Analyst, Internal Auditor and Senior Specialist Auditor. It is here where he met Sylvia Bass, and the two were joined in marriage on June 27, 1992 and were happily married until death.
]]>

item.title: Robert L. Drummond Sr.
item.description:
ï»¿November 30, 1939 - November 13, 2020
On November 30, 1939, Floyd Foster Sr. and Fannie Clark welcomed a new addition to their family. Robert Leroy Drummond better known as "Bob" was born in Detroit, Michigan and was raised in a home with strong Christian values. At an early age he accepted Christ as his Lord and savior at Clinton Street Greater Bethlehem Temple in Michigan.
Bob was "Daddy" to all of his children's and yes he had many. Daddy had several loves of his life and whether married or not, if his current love had children, those kids were his. He did not make a difference. To him, they were all biological children born to Bob, and his love to each was unconditional.
Though we called him "Daddy" he had many nick names. "Cool Breeze," "Bulldog," and to some of his closet friends he was "Bobcat". The stories behind those names will rest with "Daddy and his closet friends had better keep their lips sealed. He was a smooth cat and would often say "you better ask somebody".
On November 13, 2020, Bob made his transition from labor to rest. He fought a good fight and remained faithful to God's word. Though we grieve heavily today, we know we shall see him again.
]]>

Thus, today we celebrate the drafting of a soldier which has been called home to her final post. Ms. Alice Mae Kelly, we salute you job well done.

item.title: Harold David Anderson
item.description:
December 28, 1950 - November 11, 2020
Harold David Anderson was born December 28, 1950 to Amos Cornelius and Mary Esther Anderson (Kennedy). Although the Anderson family famously hails from Chicago, Illinois, Harold was born during the family vacation in Camden, Mississippi. This alone should have been a sign that Harold's life would turn out to be nothing short of remarkable. Harold would be the third child out of a total of 11. He would go on to self-proclaim himself, "A.C. Anderson's oldest boy and Mary Anderson's Pride & Joy". Growing up on Chicago's westside provided Harold with a colorful childhood that would begin to illustrate his journey through life. Harold loved to tell stories of his youth to any and everybody willing to listen..
Â Anecdotes ranging from neighborhood tussles to protect his sisters to bouts of heroic athleticism to save the day; Harold loved to reminisce about the early years of his life that played a pivotal role in his upbringing. He graduated from Farragut High School in 1969 and wore that accomplishment with pride; Harold was a very proud admiral. He regularly attended the annual alumni picnic to enjoy the camaraderie of his fellow admirals. Harold would go on to attend the esteemed University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. This was a huge accomplishment and milestone not only for Harold but for the Anderson family as a whole.
Upon graduation in 1973, he became the first member of his family to receive a college education. Throughout college, he played semi-pro softball with his team, The Tumble Inn. Harold was know as "the hitting machine" and easily became one of the league's premier players. He earned All-American honors with the team and created lifelong bonds that would continue for the rest of his life.Â 
Even with Harold's life thus far being a significant success in Illinois, he craved something more. His desire for success and achievement drove him to leave his home state and relocated toÂ  Los Angeles, California, in 1973 Naturally gifted with charisma, good looks, and a passion for drama - Harold decided to try his hand in the entertainment industry with dreams and aspirations of becoming an actor. While working many oddball gigs to make ends meet during his acting days, One particular job proved to be more vital than any other one.
While working as a bouncer in 1978 at a popular nightclub, Little J's, Harold met the love of his life , Denise, for the first time. As HDA would have said, " That's all she wrote!"
Harold quickly realized that Denise would be the woman he would marry and start a life with but to do so, he needed to earn money to support a family. It was a no-brainer that he had to stop chasing his acting dreams and find a suitable career to make that goal achievable. Harold would then go on to begin an illustrious career in the insurance industry., landing his first job with Liberty Mutual as a salesman. Finding much success in the industry, he began to settle in and explore the endless opportunities that the sector presented to him.
Involving himself in every aspect from worker's compensation claims management to operations management to marketing and sales. and before retiring WC nurse case management, he was determined to make his name known throughout the business.
Insurance provided Harold with a foundation to start his family with Denise and their first child, Amber. They were married 1983 in front of a small group of friends and family in Las Vegas, Nevada. Family life proved to be everything Harold had hoped for; he was a natural fit for the role of patriarch. After years of being a father of one, HDA decided it was time to bring a new child into the family. In 1989, Harold and Denise welcomed their son, Jason, into the world.
Harold would prove to be an ideal father for both Amber and Jason. His righteous morals and infinite knowledge combined with his natural trait of being a great provider allowed his children to receive a fulfilling and rewarding childhood under his and Denise's care. Both Amber and Jason gave Harold and Denise 3 beautiful grandkids - Paris, Dylan, and Sloan. All of his kids were the apple of his eye. His family's happiness was and remained a top priority. Despite being fully committed to his family. Harold still possessed the time and energy to be a leader in the professional arena.
Embarking on many endeavors throughout his career, including opening a workers compensation training school, Adjuster Academy, HDA would achieve success in much more than the insurance industry. During a hiatus, he went on to work as a government lobbyist for David Cunningham and Associates. Harold enjoyed the path he had been on for 30+ years, but the business world wasn't the only thing he was interested in. He had a deep love for fiction novels, which led to him writing and publishing two crime thriller novels of his own. "Friendly Enterprise" and "Dirty lies in the name of God" were two of Harold's most significant accomplishments. Both books were well received by readers all over the nation.
After a very extensive and successful career, Harold finally decided it was time to retire from the professional world in 2018. Harold and Denise decided to relocate to Las Vegas, Nevada, where they would start a new chapter of their lives together. Little did they know, their new home would quickly become a hotspot for visitors from all over. Without a doubt, Harold loved hosting his friends and family whenever they would come into town. This was nothing new: HDA has and will always be known as a welcoming, entertaining, and caring host for anyone who entered his life. That's just who he was.
]]>

item.title: Sharon Autrey-Wilson
item.description:
September 6, 1953 - September 29, 2020
Sharon Marie Autrey-Wilson was born on September 6, 1953 to Hillie Autrey, and Shirley Autrey (Both proceeded in death) in Brewton, Alabama. Sharon was the eldest of her seven sister's She loved all of her sister's deeply. They are Jaqueline Pringle-Clark, Eva Fisher, Carlos Kimble, Sheila Ellis (Proceeded in death), Kathy Autery-MIlan, Hilda Autrey and Kim Autrey.
At the age of 14 Sharon moved to Las Vegas, Nevada with her mother and step-father Joseph Carter (Proceeded in death), which everyone called Daddy Joe. Sharon's motherÂ  and Daddy Joe a opted seven children and raised them as his own.Â  Sharon affectionately welcomed her new brother's and sister's and referred to them as "kids" up until her death, although her youngest brother is in his forties. Her sister's and brother's name are as follows: Eric Carter, Gertrude Cater, Jessie Carter, Gerald Carter, Juanita Carter, LaTasha Carter(Proceeded in death), and James Carter.
Sharon graduated from Valley High School in 1972. She attended the university of Nevada Las Vegas with a major in communications. During her time at UNLV she met and befriended Greg Glover. They were later married in 1974, and they eagerly celebrated the arrival of their first daughter Shasta, in 1975. Greg and Sharon were blessed with their second daughter Tara, in 1982.
Sharon entered the communications field in her early twenties and held various jobs from long distance Operator to communications specialist. Sharon later retired at the University Medical Center after over twenty years dedication to putting a smile on the faces of all, with her smooth and welcoming voice. During Sharon's time at UMC she met her second husband Stanley Wilson (Proceeded in death). She welcomed her stepchildren lovingly. Their names are as follows Sherry Smith, Stanley Johnson, Hammoribi Wilson, and Stannita Wilson.
Sharon was know for her being beautiful both side and out. She had a magnetic personality and brilliant smile! Sharon was consistently dressed to nine, or as she would say "Cleaner than the board of health!" Sharon was a magnificent cook, although she was always concerned about her figure therefore, she didn't cook too often. Sharon has many family and friends that she has left a lasting effect on. She will be missed by her six grandchildren which as follows: Jabarri Glover, Jvontay Rogers, Oshalay McCree, Kevin Rogers Jr., Timara McCree, and Jordyn McCree. Sharon had a positive impact onÂ  her son-in-laws Timothy McCree and Julius Christian. Sharon has 5 great grandchildren, many nieces, nephews, brother-in-laws, great-nieces, and great-nephews, which will dearly miss her as well.
Sharon accepted Christ at an early age. She was a member of Moments of Blessing Church under the leadership of Bishop Tommy Collier. Sharon's legacy will live on beyond the years that she was present on this earth with us. Her favorite saying were: "That person is too lazy to work at a pie factory tasting pies", That person is madder than an alligator when the pond went dry, "Show meÂ  your friends and I'll show you,Â  you," "two can't walk together unless they agree," "It's not about where you've been but, where you're going" and " Take care of your business before it takes care of you."
Sharon loved to laugh and tell stories about her past. she loved to sing and could quote the bible like an old Southern Preacher.

She was motivated and ambitious woman, who loved God, and it showed through her interaction with everyone. But she was also known to be sassy and had no problem with telling you how she felt, she was bold, strong, courageous, very independent, charismatic, a leader, and a role model.
She was an amazing mother, a great mother in law, sister, auntie, cousin and friend. Virgie was a fighter, she fought till she couldn't fight anymore. She was the Champ of all champs, a true Boss lady and matriarch. She always showed unconditional love to all she came in contact with.

item.title: Tauese Isabella Semeatu
item.description:
August 16, 1955 - August 6, 2020

Our mother Tauese Isabella Semeatu, was born in Saleimoa, Samoa to Semeatu and Paepaetele Maiava. She was raised by her aunt (her mother's sister) Aaone and late Rev. Enosa. She attended most of her primary and secondary schooling in Manontai and later at A'ana College, Samoa. Our mom moved to the village of Afonotele, American Samoa, to care and tend to her parents and grandparents.

She also completed her last 2 years of secondary education at Samoana High School in American Samoa. After High School, she attended and graduated from America Samoa Community College (ASCC) in Malaeimi, class of 1980. Our mom had a passion for higher education and pursued her dreams of getting her Bachelor's degree from Chaminade University.

Our mom started her career with the Department of Education in America Samoa. She was dedicated and committed to serving our government, community, families, and the children of American Samoa as a teacher for 30 years. She taught at Matafao Elementary School, Pago Pago Elementary, Afonotele Elementary School, and Aua Elementary School. She became a pillar in the education system and was recognized as Teacher of the Year many times.

Our mom was a God-fearing woman! She dedicated her time and service to her church, community, family, and especially her children. She was a member of the Afonotele Ekalesia Fa'apotopotoga Kerisiano I America Samoa (EFKAS) church. She was a Sunday school teacher and a member of the Mafutaga Tina. Our mom was also an esteemed and respected member of her village of Afonotele. She was part of the "Aualuma" (Talaleomalie, Faletua and Tausi) representing the Matagaono Family.

After her retirement from the Department of Education in American Samoa, mom decided to move to California to be with her children. She continued with the Lord's work and became a member of the Long Beach First Congregational church (EFKS) under the direction of her cousin Rev. Momoli and Mafa Papali'i. She later moved to North Las Vegas, Nevada with her children and became a member of the Ekalesia Fa'apotopotoga Kerisiano North Las Vegas church. She was later appointed and serve as a Ta'ita'i Tiakono (Lead Deacon) for 5 years

Our mom love spending time tending to her garden, cleaning the yard and her home, and taking care of her mother, children, and grandchildren. She also loved having fun and enjoyed going to the Casinos and bingo. Our mom had a heart of gold, who loved all and would open her heart and home to anyone. For those who knew her, she was the life of the party and always the star of the show. She was confident, funny, and strong. Yet, she was very humble, selfless, compassionate, caring and loving. In her last remaining days despite the obstacles she has faced, she continued to be selfless. She strived to care for children and her grandchildren, including taking orders from lil' Vai. Mom, we promised to keep your spirit and legacy alive. Always know that you are loved by so many and will be missed by all, especially your children

]]>

item.title: George L. McFadden
item.description:
April 14, 1964 - September 5, 2020

George L. McFadden Sr was born April, 14, 1964 in Lake City, South Carolina.
George graduated from Lake City High (Class of 1982). During his time he played basketball and was also an avid racquetball player. George joined the United States Airforce in 1983 and retired in 2003. After serving 20 years in the military George went on to become the first African American to become a supervisor for the Clark County Work Department Division. George performed 13 years of service prior to a medical retirement.
George gave his life to Christ in 2008 and was baptized in 2010 under the leadership of Pastor Luther McCaskill of the Las Vegas Worship Center. He was known for encouraging others to live a life of Christ and was always willing to give his time, talent and money to anyone he came across..

He was known for his big heart and being a giver.
He may not have always told you what you wanted to hear but he always told you how it actually was. George will be sorely missed. He and his McFadden family shared an amazing bond as well as the Stewart family after meeting and marrying Tracy Cowart upon arrival in Las Vegas, NV.

]]>

item.title: Tonisha MayoÂ
item.description:
Sunrise April 11,1974Â  Sunset August 28,2020
With profound sadness we announce the passing of Tonisha Mayo, Our loving and devoted mother and friend to all whose lives she touched, August 28, 2020. She left us while sleeping peacefully at her resident in Las Vegas, Nevada. She was in her 46th year. Born in Phoenix, Arizona, to Ruby Green and Donald Mayo. The youngest of 5 children by Ruby. Later, residing in southern California, then finally residing in Nevada.

During her time on earth, approximately 20 of those years, Tonisha battled a serious drug addiction. Through family support, perseverance and desire to be 'clean' she overcame her addiction. In 2017. she was able to regain custody of her youngest son, Kevondrey. However, this would not be her last earthly test. She was recently diagnosed with chronic strokes and a seizure disorder.

Tonisha, being a God fearing woman, was counting her blessings, as she was anxiously awaiting her first grandchild. Her daughter, Tanaya, was only 9 weeks away from giving birth.Â  Tonisha loved to draw, give the Lord his praise, and continue to better herself everyday. Most of all, she loved her family and instilled in her children strong values that have served them well. Her final years were spent as being a devoted homeworker.Â 
]]>

item.title: Stacy Nicole Latimore Johnson
item.description:
Sunrise February 16,1982Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Sunset May 22,2020
Stacy was born to the loving parents of Walter Bernard and Philecia Elaine Patterson on in February 16,1982 in the state of California. Stacy lived in Pomona and Paramount California for the first few years of her life. In 1987 her father married Ivy Lynn and she and her father raised Stacy. The family then moved to Las Vegas in 1996 and she finished school here in Nevada. Stacy gave her life to Christ in 1998, at Mountaintop Faith Ministries. There she sang in the youth choir.
She met Demetrius Horton and they welcomed a wonderful baby girl, Deanna Ja'sha Horton on February 16,2000. Then she met and fell in love with Armechie Lamar Johnson in June 2000 and they were married October 29, 2008. In their marriage they welcomed a daughter, Za'Kiya Nicole and a son, Armechie Lamar Hohnson Jr. She loved her family unconditionally and her children meant the world to her. She was the best mother she could be. She was a very positive and loving person. Her favorite words when things were not going right was The devil is a lie. Then she would regroup and pull things together. On May 22, 2020 Stacy Nicole stepped out of time into eternity.

item.title: Sabrina Dunson
item.description:
Sunrise July. 4,1964Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â Sunset October.4,2020
Sabrina Dunson was born July 4,1964 in Las Vegas , Nevada to Edward Bradford and Veola Chappaz-Bradford. Born one of seven children Sabrina attended several schools within the Clark County District : Von Tobel Middle school , Rancho and Eldorado High School . Brina worked housekeeping for the casino and cleaning houses. She accepted Christ at a young age .Sabrina was a lovingÂ  wife , mother , grandma ,cousin and friend. She had a heart of gold and was the backbone of our family.

She was truly an angel that was full of love . Brina cared about everyone that entered her life and was always there for you and gave you the best advice. She was just a phone call away. Sabrina was a strong warrior that never gave up. No matter what she faced in life she made sure you were alright. She enjoyed being a mother and granny to her kids and grandchildren. Brina was always picture ready, that her style and ability to dress was second to none. She loved being cute that her nickname was "Cutie".

Her hobbies were house shopping, clothes shopping, cooking, nail salon, joking around, cleaning, watching her T.V. shows. Listening to music was her calm as she was getting ready for her doctor's appointments. Sabrina strong points was bringing the family together. To meet her was to love her. She was passionate, loving, caring, very independent, and life of the party.Â Â

item.description:
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â SunriseÂ  Â -Â  Â February 8, 1954Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  SunsetÂ  Â -Â  Â August 25, 2020Â 
Robert Lee Spencer Jr. was born February 8, 1954 in Las Vegas, Nevada to Robert L. Spencer Sr. and Lillie L Spencer. He was the second born of five children. Robert was affectionately known as "Bob" or "Sly" his stage name. Bob grew up in West Las Vegas where he attended West side school for kindergarten. He learned to play the trumpet while he attended Madison Elementary and Cashman Junior High school. Bob was in the Western High School marching band where he graduated from in 1972. During his early years Bob developed a love of music, he was self-taught and was able to play the organ by ear. During his high school years, he was in a band called the Band of gypsy he was the key board player his band played several venues around Las Vegas. As a young boy Bob learned about Jehovah God and he still believed in Jehovah God and the resurrection hope.
In the 1986 he met Miranda Clark while working at Circus Circus as a cook. She became his best friend and mother to his son. Bob retired from Circus Circus and worked as a security guard until he fell ill. Robert will truly be missed by all because he was loved by all.
]]>

item.title: Christopher Bill Williams
item.description:
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â SunriseÂ  Â -Â  Â November 11, 2003Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  SunsetÂ  Â -Â  Â August 23, 2020
Only One Way
I sit here and think of how it should have been; not me, the pen. I guess it's too late and it doesn't matter; all it does is make me sadder. I think of the this, I wish I could change then I know why people think of me as strange. They walk by me and nod their head, but I know deep down they wish I were dead. They say in the world this is no place for me, and for once in my life I must agree. For drugs and alcohol have taken control and put my life way down deep in a hole. So, I look for a way out of this mess, but there is only one way I must confess. It's a long a long hard road to change your ways and it happens really slowly, day by day. There is one, you see, he's always there his only deal is to love and care. For he is the one who made us all, he'll always help you when you fall. it's the Lord, you see, he'll never leave you. All he asks is that you believe in him. So, when you face life's little troubles, call on God, he's there on the double. So, when people ask how to get relief, I humbly say, repent and believe. And that is about all I need to say.
By Shontell B.
]]>

item.title: Sedric Earl Shorter
item.description:
SunriseÂ  Â February 18, 1970Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â SunsetÂ  Â July 28, 2020
Sedric Earl Shorter was born on February 18, 1970 to Solon Earl Shorter and Earline Shorter in Las Vegas,NV. He was preceded in death by his mother in 1981.

Sedric Shorter remained in Las Vegas, NV and attended Chaparral High School. He played football at Chaparral, filling the position as an outside Linebacker, in where he once held the record for the most Quarterback sacks. After graduating and receiving his Diploma in 1988, Sedric joined the Marines. He was relieved from from his duties in 1990. From there, Sedric attended Orange Coast College in Costa Mesa, CA to pursue a degree in Criminal Justice from 1991-1992. Sedric received a football scholarship and attended Washington State University while pursuing a degree in Criminal Justice from 1992 - 1993. Sedric gained many stats with The Cougars and played alongside (quarterback then) Drew Bledsoe. In 1993, The Cougars defeated the University of Bakersfield Roadrunners and won the Weiser Lock Copper Bowl. Due to an unforseen Achilles injury, this prevented Sedric from having an opportunity to play in the NFL. He went on to play Semi-Pro football as an outside LineBacker oversees in Amsterdam from 1994 -1997. In 1994 Sedric's team won the Swede Bowl and received the SAFF Gold medal and trophy in defeating their rivals.

Sedric relocated back to Las Vegas, NV and worked along side his friend, Glen Learner's law firm. He traveled around the world in style. Sedric always kept a smile on his face. He enjoyed being around his fellow brotherhood and cousins. Sedric was a people's person who enjoyed life and loved to have fun. He was a, "Lively One" who was considered, "The Life of a Party"Â 

Sedric was an active church member of New Bethel Baptist for the most part of his life. At and early age, he was baptized, accepting Jesus Christ as our Lord and Savior. He filled the position of a dedicated choir member for many years. Sedric departed this life, peacefully in his sleep on July 28, 2020.Â 
]]>

Wilbert Pollard was born March 21, 1950 in St. Joseph, Louisiana, to the union of Jesse and Perline Pollard. Wilbert graduated in 1969 from Tensas Rosenwald High School in St. Joseph, Louisiana. Wilbert accepted Christ at an early age and was baptized by the late Pastor A.E. Durham of China Grove B.C. of St. Joseph, LA. Wilbert relocated to Oakland , California and became employed at the Oakland Zoo. After many years he returned back to his home town of St. Joseph, LA where he became employed as a City Worker until his retirement. He returned back to visit his children in Oakland and Antioch California. Later he came to visit with his siblings in Las Vegas, NV, however, he remained with them until his death.

Charles Lay Jr. Was born July 31, 1949 in Atalla, Mississippi to Charles Lay Sr. and Thelma Ruth Dodd. Charles departed this life on July 8, 2020 at Mt. View Hospital. He moved to Las Vegas at an early age and attended Las Vegas High School where he later graduated. He was enlisted in the armed Forces (Army) October 12, 1970 for a short time where he later received an honorable discharged. He received the National Defense Service Medal, Marksmanship badge, Driver award, and a Good Conduct medal. Charles was active in church until he took ill. His work history included many. He was a cleaning technician and later owned his own company, C&C Detail. He also worked in the hotel industry as a cook and later promoted to chef.Â

item.title: Willie Andrew Sanford
item.description:
Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â SunriseÂ  Â -Â  Â December 31st, 1943Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â -Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â SunsetÂ  Â -Â  Â July 19th, 2020
Willie Andrew Sanford, was born December 31, 1943 in Mcintyre, Georgia to the union of Walter Adam and Gussie Mae Sanford. At the tender age of three, his parents decided to relocate to Detroit Michigan, along with hi oldest brother, Walter Jr. now with the family in Michigan three more children were born and the family of five was settled.

While growing up in Detroit, he attended Jose Campau Elementary and North Eastern High School. With his facetious humor, he would tell his children he had to walk three miles to school uphill, in the snow but the schools were literally right across the street from his childhood home on Mitchell St.

Willie eyed the love of his life Doris Jackson while they both attended North Eastern High School. They were high school sweethearts and during the short time of their courtship, their love grew stronger and they knew they were meant to be . Upon graduation their hearts locked and the two never separated.

Aspiring more out of life than what Detroit or it's factories had to offer.Â  Willie enlisted into the United States Navy in January of 1962. Immediately after returning from bootcamp he claimed his love and married her on June 12, 1962in Detroit, Michigan. Willie served in the U.S. Navy as a dental Technician during Vietnam and was also a member of the Navy Band yielding his shiny brass trumpet during ceremonies.
The union of Willie and Doris brought about three children, William Andrew Sanford, Yolawnda Ladonna Sanford and Douglas Andrew Sanford each of their children were born in different location due to Willie's deployments; South Carolina, San Diego and Las Vegas. In 1966, Willie & Doris moved their family to Las Vegas because of the Secret Naval Base in Nevada and it became their home. As a dedicated family man Willie worked to provide for his family, while he and Doris were thousand miles away from their families in Detroit, Michigan.

Once settled in Las Vegas, he worked at first Interstate Bank as one of the first African American bank tellers. Willie also worked at the Nevada test site as a security officer and with that experience he later worked at the infamous Thunderbird Hotel & Casino. He also spent time working for Sears & Robucks CO. In the credit approval department and even was a bus driver for CCSD. However 'Will" affectionately called by some, served a dedicated 35 years as a crap dealer at Bally's Casino formally known as the MGM Grand . By God's grace, he was off work the day the widely televised MGM fired occurred. His work ethic spoke for itself as he earned numerous quality control and customer service awards.

After retiring from Bally's Willie spent his retired years spending quality time with his wife Doris, hanging with his grandchildren and great grandchildren or shopping at Lowe's. If we fail to mention how handy he was with hands and tools there would be a price to pay. He could be found doing all types of repairs including electrical, plumbing, auto repairs, ETC. You name it Willie could do it. On one occasion it's remembered how he came home to a hole in the wall because his love Doris wanted to change the floor plan of their second home. When he told her it couldn't be done she took a hammer and put holes in the walls right where she wanted the new access after he left for work. Well of course he was surprised but all she told him him was, "Baby you can fix it" she was always the wind beneath his wings! Shortly after retirement, Willie began to live a life with Parkinson's Disease.Â  While this diagnosis was unexpected, it never stopped him from enjoying life. He continued doing the things he enjoyed. It may have taken a bit longer or even been a bit dangerous but nothing was stopping him.

Those who knew Willie knew that he was very stylish; from his hat to his shoes everything had to be "Top Notch". Willie's style didn't stop at his clothing but extended to his vehicles, high quality jewelry and food. It was very common to find him eating a steak or lobster on a seemingly often occasion. While out dining he would often tell others with him, "Get what you want". As he would sit back in a humble fashion and just enjoy his family.

His Charismatic personality was priceless and his smile infectious. He was soft spoken and always had a word of encouragement, wisdom and/or advice when you needed it. He and Doris had no choice except to become parents of all the friends their children would bring home, not because they necessarily wanted too but because they were adopted by so many. A father to more than his own children and an example to all of what a man should be. he was a husband, father, protector and provider. He will be remembered by many nicknames to those touched "Honey", "Dad", "Granddaddy", Dollar Bill", "King" & "Hardways Will" Oh yea! If on the craps table any players placed a tip on the "Hardways" for the dealers, They could always count on Willie to call the "Hardways" hince "Hardways Will".

Willie did not speak of his faith often and you would not see him in church every Sunday or praying before he went to sleep. However, he would fellowship with his family at their ministries everytime he was invited. His favorite church hymmn was "I'm going up yonder" and he accepted Christ as his Lord and savior.
]]>

item.title: Paepaetele Moimoi Semeatu Maiava
item.description:
SunriseÂ  Â -Â  Â May 17th, 1929Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â -Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â SunsetÂ  Â -Â  Â July 7th, 2020Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â  Â 
Paepaetele Moimoi Matagaono Semeatu Maiava was truly blessed. She was born May 17, 1929 in Fagamalo, Amerika Samoa to Matagaono Tauapa'i Moimoi Loa and Urima Akeripa Sepania Pula. She was married to Ma'afu Tuna Semeatu Maiava and raised 9 children in the village of Afonotele, Amerika Samoa.Â Paepaetele attended Saleimoa elementary school and Papauta all-girls school in Upolu, Somoa. She also later attended the Poyer school "A'oga a Poia" pago, Amerika Samoa.Â 
Paepaetele worked and retired from Starkist canneries in Amerika Samoa after 30 years of service. She dedicated her services and time to her family, church, and her village of Afonotele. She was a deacon for the church of Ekalesia Fa'apototpotoga Kerisiano I Amerika Samoa (EFKAS). She was an active member of the church choir and "Mafutaga a Tina". She was the leader of the "aualuma" (Talaleleomalie, Faletua, and Tausi) representing the Matagaono Family. She spent most of her time sitting on her father's grave, either singing, telling stories, napping, or making beautiful leis for the church.
Sometimes you would find her in the "umu" helping out, doing laundry, cleaning or planting flowers around her home. She always loved to stay busy. She was content and blessed with the love and life that she had.Â Paepaetelepassed away peacefully surrounded by her family on Tuesday July 7, 2020 in our family home in Las Vegas, NV. She will always be remembered as a loving and selfless wife, mother and grandmother. She had a tender heart and loved to spoil her grandchildren. She had a quiet strength and always smiled even when times were tough. She was loved by many and will be missed by all.Â 
]]>
